table-wrap.anchoringText: Table 1 shows correlation coefficients among several variables in the Rough Rider Middle Bakken database. As an example, 180-day cumulative oil/ft is negatively correlated to water cut with a correlation coefficient (r) of – 0.44. One hundred eighty-day cumulative oil/ft and frac fluid pumped (bbl/ft) are positively correlated (r – 0.34).
table-wrap.label: Table 1
table-wrap.caption: Correlation coefficients for the Middle Bakken laterals (Rough Rider Area)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Correlation coefficients for the Middle Bakken laterals (Rough Rider Area)

table-wrap.anchoringText: Table 2 compares the R-squared, training RMSE, and test RMSE values of all the models using the Rough Rider Middle Bakken data. The RMSE is in BO/ft. As expected, the test RMSEs are higher than the training RMSEs for all the models Again, a training RMSE of 1.527 BO/ft, for example, means that on average there is about a 15,270 barrel-of-oil uncertainty in the predicted 180-day cumulative oil/10,000-ft lateral.
table-wrap.label: Table 2
table-wrap.caption: Overall regression results, Rough Rider Middle Bakken data

formatted-caption.caption-text: Overall regression results, Rough Rider Middle Bakken data

table-wrap.anchoringText: Table 3 is an example of the sensitivities of only completion-related variables on the predicted 180-day cumulative oil/ft using the AIC chosen model shown previously (due to space constraints, we will show the sensitivity results of the other models in Figure 7). These sensitivities were performed by holding all of the predictors constant (at their mean values) except for the predictor of interest. The change in the predicted 180- day cumulative oil/ft is noted and compared to the base case (in green).
table-wrap.label: Table 3
table-wrap.caption: A sensitivity of completion parameters on the predicted 180-day cumulative oil/ft using the AIC chosen model, Rough Rider Middle Bakken data

formatted-caption.caption-text: A sensitivity of completion parameters on the predicted 180-day cumulative oil/ft using the AIC chosen model, Rough Rider Middle Bakken data

table-wrap.anchoringText: The multiple regression model 1 consisting of eight predictors results in an R-squared of 0.54 and a training RMSE of 1.745 BO/ft whereas the multiple regression model 2 gives an R-squared of 0.70 with training RMSE of 1.408 BO/ft. Figure 10 is the predicted versus observed 180-day cumulative oil/ft for the BIC and AIC chosen models, and Figure 11 is the same plot for the random forests and GBM. The R-squared, training RMSE, and test RMSE values of all the models for the Three Forks data are given in Table 4.
table-wrap.label: Table 4
table-wrap.caption: Overall regression results, Rough Rider Three Forks data

formatted-caption.caption-text: Overall regression results, Rough Rider Three Forks data

table-wrap.anchoringText: Table 5 shows the sensitivities of only completion-related variables on the predicted 180-day cumulative oil/ft using the AIC chosen model. Again, these sensitivities were performed by holding all of the predictors constant (at their mean values) except for the predictor of interest. The change in the predicted 180-day cumulative oil/ft is noted and compared to the base case (in green). The numbers in dark orange are greater than two standard deviations from the mean of the predictor of interest.
table-wrap.label: Table 5
table-wrap.caption: A sensitivity of completion parameters on the predicted 180-day cumulative oil/ft using the AIC chosen model, Rough Rider Three Forks data

formatted-caption.caption-text: A sensitivity of completion parameters on the predicted 180-day cumulative oil/ft using the AIC chosen model, Rough Rider Three Forks data

table-wrap.caption: Appendix A-1 Multiple regression model 1 (Middle Bakken)
